Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Investigating patterns and processes of evolution, ecology, and diversification in carangiform fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines genetic diversity in two species of iconic marine fishes, the Giant Trevally and the Bluefin Trevally. Both species are top predators on coral and rocky reefs throughout the Indian and Pacific Oceans and are highly valued for artisanal, commercial, and sport fisheries. The research will investigate the correlation between genetic diversity and environmental variables (e.g., ocean temperature and currents) in the Indo-Pacific to identify physical barriers that might lead to observed differences in the genomes of these fishes in different geographic locations. The project focuses on the western Indian Ocean, a region lacking sufficient marine conservation measures in large part due to a scarcity of data necessary to inform governments making management decisions. Given the lack of data on these two species of Trevally, coupled with their economic importance, this project has direct societal implications. The researchers will share data with governmental and non-profit collaborators and incorporate strong scientific training components for graduate students, as well as engagement with members of the public in the USA, South Africa, and Seychelles.

To accomplish the project objectives, the researchers will first conduct seascape genetic analyses using next generation sequencing techniques, specifically double digest restriction site associated DNA sequencing (RADseq) targeting single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to examine fine-scale genetic structure within and among C. ignobilis and C. melampygus individuals across their range. Seascape properties will be analyzed using coupled biological-physical models that integrate oceanographic data with biological attributes of these species. Models will be generated that maximize the availability of oceanographic information at a spatial scale complementary to the genetic data. The second component includes a phylogeographic analysis focused on characterizing patterns of historic gene flow by using paleoclimatic data to characterize physical and biological forces that may have driven evolution and influenced historical and present data distributions of the two species. This methodology uses high-resolution paleoceanographic models coupled with contemporary GIS-based species distribution modeling algorithms to generate paleodistribution suitability values for each species. These paleodistributions serve as alternate hypotheses to test against the SNP dataset. In combination, these analyses will provide insight on contemporary and historical processes shaping the diversification and connectivity of these two important fishery species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carangoids, Jacks and Pampanos, is a group of coastal pelagic marine fishes that utilize both coral reef and pelagic environments, distinguishing them from coral reef obligate and open water pelagic fishes. This thesis work attemped to investigate the population genetics of two commercially important species, the Giant Trevally (Caranx ignobilis) and Bluefin Trevally (Caranx melampygus), across the Indo-Pacific, examine spatial patterns in trophic position and niche width the Giant Trevally, and provide an evolutionary perspective on carangoid fishes through a phylogenetic analysis for 154 species in the lineage. Analyses of geographic population structure and allelic diversity indicate that the Giant Trevally and Bluefin Trevally display different phylogeographic patterns. Bluefin Trevally comprises one panmictic population across the tropical and subtropical Indo-Pacific whereas the Giant Trevally consists of two populations – one in the Central Pacific and one in the West Pacific and Indian Oceans – with restricted gene flow between them. Both species maintain gene flow across the Indonesian Archipelago, displaying patterns that resemble large pelagic predators such as sharks and tunas rather than most reef-associated teleost fishes. Analysisof 12 juvenile and 42 adult Giant Trevally of isotopic ratios of carbon (δ13C/ δ12C) and nitrogen (δ15N/ δ14N) revealed wide variation in trophic niche breadth between sampling sites and an offshore to coastal gradient in carbon that drove niche distinctiveness between localities. Our trophic position estimates places Giant Trevally at the equivalent trophic level as many predatory sharks. Analysis of DNA sequences from more than 1,100 nuclear genes and information from the fish fossil record provides a well-resolved and strongly supported time calibrated phylogeny of carangoid fishes. Analysis of geographic distributions show that 73% of carangoid sister species exhibit =sympatric geographic distributions, regardless of node age, and most co-existing across large portions of their ranges. Despite broad sympatry among sister lineages, we observe greater disparity in body size and water column depth between sympatric sister species than allopatric sister species. These and other ecological or behavioral attributes are likely facilitating sympatry among the most closely related carangoid species. Our results indicate the prevalence of sympatry at a larger scale that has previously been described in marine fishes.
